sub_title: Senior Expert (River & Reservoir Dynamics | Fluvial Geomorphology | Integrated River Basin Management | Inland Water Systems)
summary:
 More than 27 years of experience in civil engineering field, specialized in fluvial hydraulics and geomorphology with a focus on river basins, reservoirs and water infrastructures
 Engaged in a broad range of assignments worldwide that include specialized consultancy, applied research, training and capacity building programs for government and non-government authorities and institutions. 
 Regular involvement in projects related to various issues such as flow (flood) and sediment management in river basins and reservoirs, inland water transport, river training and improvement works, feasibility and impact assessment as well as disaster risk assessment and management.
 Experience of working in various river systems and reservoirs around the world from steep rivers to lowland deltas, such as Brahmaputra, Congo, Ganges, Kosi, Kaveri, Meuse, Rhône, Rhine, Amu Darya, Kura and mamy others.
 Professional experience in hydropower and dam sector, e.g. involved in iconic project - Dam Rehabilitation and Improvement Program (DRIP) in India.
 Involved in development and application of innovative technology and approaches, striving for bridging the gap between cutting-edge research and real-world practices.
 Regularly undertaking international business development activities, possessing experience with acquisition and execution of international projects, generating project ideas, preparing proposals for the projects funded by various agencies and programs (e.g. WB, ADB, EU, RVO, and other)
 Involved in supervision and guidance of university scholars and researchers, regularly publishing technical articles, and acting as a peer reviewer/guest editor for scientific journals.
 Professional member of International Association of Hydraulic Research (IAHR), International Commissions on Large Dams (ICLOD), International Hydropower Association (IHA), European Geophysical Union (EGU), member of IAHR Working Group on Reservoir Sedimentation 
 Valuable experience of residing, studying and working in different parts of the world (e.g. Netherlands, Japan, Russia, India, Nepal), dealing with variety of problems and possessing sensitivity to the people from different cultural and societal background 
 Linguistic capability comprises English, Russian (excellent), Dutch (moderate), Japanese (poor), Hindi and Nepalese (mother tongues)

projects.title: Flood and Riverbank Erosion Risk Management Investment Program (FRERMIP), Bangladesh (Phase 2)
projects.description:

projects.title: Resource management and disaster resilience in Kopili basin (Assam)
projects.description: Developing resource management system and community-based disaster risk reduction in the project area with a focus on the Kopili river basin in Assam. The project includes flood modelling and mapping of the project area with its resources, infrastructure, and land-use and cover as well as proposed hydropower dam and its impacts. It also includes the establishment of Early Warning System (EWS) catering to improve preparedness and flood response in the region as well as a comprehensive assessment of basin and river morphology, impacts on existing embankments including propositions for erosion protection measures along with the wetland development plan and the village disaster risk reduction plans that will aide in establishing a roadmap and guidance to fulfil sustainable development of the project area.

projects.title: Consultancy Services for Physical-Based Mathematical Modelling for Estimation of Sediment Generation and Transport in Seven  River Basins in India under National Hydrology Project (NHP)
projects.description: Quantification of sediment-induced problems is very important in a basin to reach scale considering all relevant natural and human-induced processes, such as proper assessment and prediction of sediment generation  at  the  catchment,  transport  and  deposition  along  river  systems,  dams  and  reservoirs.  This project  will  establish  a  methodology  for  development  and  application  of  physics-based  mathematical models  (basin- and  reach-scale).  The  models are being developed for seven basins across India, and applied to replicate catchment hydrology, river flow including overland flow (where necessary), sediment generation from catchments, its transportation mechanism through channels/rivers, retention/deposition at hydraulic structures. Besides, within the scope of this project, a comprehensive morphological analysis will  be carried out for  all seven  basins:  i) Ramganga, ii) Barak, iii) Narmada, iv) Cauvery, v) Kuttiadipuzha, vi) Peechi, and vii) Mangalam.

projects.title: Sustainable Development of Navigability at Rhine Branches (DVR)
projects.description:
The Rhine River is considered the backbone of the Northwest European waterways network. All efforts are made to ensure the navigability of the river all year round. Due to the morphological behaviour of the river, navigation is subject to hindrance in some locations and frequent maintenance is being carried out. Morphological changes of the river are predicted to increase the number of nautical bottlenecks in the coming years. 
Accordingly, the decision was then taken to create a morphological model that covers the entire Rhine branches in the Netherlands.  A detailed numerical quasi-3D morphological model based on the numerical software package Delft3D has been set up. The model covers, nearly, the entire Rhine system in the Netherlands. The model is used to analyse the long-term large-scale evolution of the system. The model aims to provide a tool for river managers, which enables assessment of the morphological response of the river to different maintenance plans as well as changes in dredging activities for a sustainable navigation channel.

projects.title: Flood and Riverbank Erosion Risk Management Investment Program, Bangladesh
projects.description:
The Flood and Riverbank Erosion Risk Management Investment Program (FRERMIP), covers three priority sites (subprojects) along both banks of the lower Jamuna and upper Padma Rivers in central Bangladesh.  Two of these three areas form the core for a comprehensive approach towards integrated flood (risk) management (IFM) in central Bangladesh (focus area),consisting of a mix of structural and non‐structural measures, closely interwoven with associated safeguards and long‐term maintenance.  River management involving stabilization and reclamation of lost flood plain land will support the IFM approach and in places extend the present floodplains into the currently active river corridor through reclamation. 
While Project1 principally addresses priority riverbank erosion issues, which is closely linked to flood management, Project2 is intended to lead to the stabilization of river reaches with more controlled floodplains, with Project-3 finally also contributing to larger scale stability, including the recovery of lost floodplain land and improved navigability.

projects.title: Climate Adaptation and Mitigation Program for Aral Sea Basin (CMAP4ASB) - Capacity building and research on hydrological modeling of reservoirs for forecasting and assessment of hydropower potential
projects.description: The CMAP4ASB aims at enhancing regionally coordinated access to climate services for key stakeholders in central Asia. The main goal of this assignment is to develop and conduct capacity building programs to enhance the knowledge and skills of professionals from national and regional authorities (mainly hydrometeorological institutes from Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan) in the field of hydropower potential assessment of planned and existing reservoirs systems. The assignment includes organization of regional and national capacity programs (trainings and workshops) on water resources, hydrology and reservoir operation modelling as well as hydropower potential. It also includes developing of curricula, organizing online courses and technical support to local professionals and authorities for pilot studies.

projects.title: Dam Rehabilitation and Improvement Project (DRIP) in India
projects.description: There are about 4900 large dams in India and about 350 are under construction. In addition, there are several thousand smaller dams. These dams are vital for ensuring the water security of the country; and they also constitute a major responsibility in terms of asset management and safety. In April 2012, the Central Water Commission (CWC) with assistance from the World Bank, embarked upon the six year Dam Rehabilitation and Improvement Project (DRIP) at an estimated cost of Rs. 2100 crore. The project originally envisaged the rehabilitation and improvement of about 223 dams within four states - namely, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha & Tamil Nadu - with provision for taking up some more dams in other states; the actual numbers may vary owing to the addition / deletion of dams during implementation (click current status). The project will also promote new technologies and improve Institutional capacities for dam safety evaluation and implementation at the Central and State levels and in some identified premier academic and research institutes of the country. The Central Dam Safety Organisation of Central Water Commission, assisted by an Engineering and Management Consulting firm, is coordinating and supervising the Project implementation.

projects.title: Hydraulic and morphological effects of the river improvement works and alternatives in Congo River at Brazzaville
projects.description: The project regards regards investigations of hydraulic and morphodynamic effects of the river improvement works and the alternatives for improving the navigability in the Congo River at Brazzaville.  This includes investigation on evolution of channel planform and short-term prediction based on probabilistic approach for channel abandonment and migration, supported by the analysis of satellite images. Furthermore, investigation was carried out to assess hydraulic and morphodynamic effects of the proposed river improvement works and other possible alternatives essentially using two-dimensional morphological modelling of the selected reach, supported by analyses of historical data, bathymetry measurements and satellite images.

projects.title: Room for the River Project in The Netherlands
projects.description: The goal of the Dutch Room for the River Programme is to give the river more room to be able to manage higher water levels. At more than 30 locations, measures will be taken that give the river space to flood safely. Moreover, the measures will be designed in such a way that they improve the quality of the immediate surroundings. The Room for the River programme will be completed by approximately 2016.

projects.title: Flood Prevention Program Azerbaijan
projects.description: The general project objectives were threefold: 1) determine the condition of the flood defences along the Kura and the Araz after the 2010 flood event (baseline study), 2) design short term actions to prevent floods in 2011 and 3) draft a national plan for an integrated water management and flood prevention program for the next 5 years, including the institutional settings. As part of the Flood Prevention Program, a hydraulic and morphological models of the rivers Kura and Araz were developed as a tool to predict flow and morphological processes and impact assessment of various preventive measures.
